Award.AwardTitle: RTG: Analysis, Geometry, and Topology at Rice University
Award.AbstractNarration:
Rice University has a dynamic geometry group, with senior faculty in low- dimensional topology; quasi-crystals, spectral theory, and mathematical physics; geometric measure theory; algebraic and complex geometry; and Teichmueller theory and minimal surfaces. This project will support a Research Training Group led by these faculty, involving undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows. Our main objective is to increase the number of students and postdocs pursuing independent research in geometry, as well as related areas of topology and analysis.

Geometric problems stimulate progress across almost every subfield of mathematics. The study of conic sections initiated by the ancient Greeks spurred the development of coordinate systems and polynomial algebra in the 17th century, leading to the modern field of algebraic geometry. The desire to find curves and surfaces minimizing the energy of physical systems motivated the development of calculus. More recently, geometric questions about knots and links have led to numerous advances in modern algebra. Thus geometric examples offer common ground where specialists in different areas can exchange ideas and techniques. The Geometry Group at Rice builds on this common ground to train students and postdoctoral fellows in the methods of mathematical research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This RTG grant supported a dynamic group of undergraduates, graduate students, and postdocs in their efforts to do independent research in geometry and related topics and fostered connections across different specialties within the research group.

Broader Impact: 36 graduate students were trained by the grant, resulting in 15 (at the conclusion of the funding period) new Mathematics Ph.D. recipients entering the scientific workforce.  These new professional mathematicians work in the academy, in industry, and in government facilities. The grant supported 4 postdocs who expanded their research and teaching scope and record, and led undergraduate research groups. A conference in Algebraic Geometry ran with 48 participants from across the country, with lectures by leading mathematicians aimed at younger participants. There are now about 5 seminars running in the Rice Mathematics department that have become routine through the course of this grant, at least one for each of the PIs: these seminars provide disciplinary training for the graduate students and postdocs, as well as experience in presentation. Undergraduate research projects were run in the various research areas represented by the PIs.

Intellectual Merit: Scientific advances were developed in the areas of analysis, topology and geometry, disseminated via the publication of 37 papers by the supported participants and co-authors.
